attributes.title: Stock Take
attributes.description: Physical stock counted compared to SAP warehouse inventory balances revealed variances as follows;-  Finished products had -40.75 loaves, Utto had -2.754Ltrs, White flour had +7.794kgs, Brown flour had +10.87kgs, while Polybags had  -212 pieces. The rest of the stock items had immaterial variance.
attributes.recommendation:
•    Despite the minimal variance on polybags, the branch management should tighten controls on variety-wise polybags and especially the Naivas varieties. 
•    The controls in place on all other stock items should be maintained to safeguard against any loss.
attributes.effect: •    Minimal variations in stock items implies that good controls are in place that safeguard company against losses.

value:
•    The supervisors on duty have been tasked to ensure that actual production align variety wise to minimise variety wise polybags variances.
•    We shall ensure that all other stock items are properly controlled.
•    Variations are minimal, will put more control on utto

•    In prior audit, the following were the stock findings; 
    Bread stock showed a surplus of 13.5 Loaves,
    Packing material had  a surplus of +716 pieces,
    White flour had a surplus of +1.96 kgs,
    Brown flour had had  a surplus of +0.30kgs,
    Wheat bran had had  a deficit of -5.00kgs,
    Utto experienced a variance of -12.32kgs,
    Other material items had minimal variances.
•    Stock take was conducted on 24th May 2025 to ascertain whether the physical stocks were matching with the stock book balance in SAP system and whether internal controls on stocks were effective.
•    Minimal variations in stock items implies that good controls are in place that safeguard company against losses.
Operations/Production Department
To ascertain whether the physical stocks were matching with the stock book balance in SAP system and whether internal controls on stocks were effective.

attributes.title: Bread Weight Check
attributes.description: •    From the samples picked, bread underweight were noted across all varieties as follows; 200g ML – 35%, 400g W – 1%, 400g Brown – 15%, 600g W – 39%, 800g W – 9% and 1.5kg W – 13%. Finding illustrated below;
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch management should adhere to all set production standards to eliminate cases of underweight.
•    Enforcement of weight check at the slicing table to avoid packing underweight bread.
attributes.effect:
•    Presence of underweight bread exposes the company to the risk of regulatory penalties if caught by Weights and Measures officials in the market.
•    Supplying underweight bread may lead to consumer dissatisfaction and brand tarnishing.

value: •    Underweight on some varieties is majorly as a result of overcooling. We will shall monitor the slicers to ensure no bread is left to overcool.
•    Noted, will check on temperature and also cooling time to avoid over cooling.
•    In prior audit, bread underweight were noted as follows;–

•    Bread weight check was done from a selected sample of packed bread ready to be dispatched to the market. The aim was to establish whether, bread dispatched to the market meets the required weight standards.

•    Presence of underweight bread exposes the company to the risk of regulatory penalties if caught by Weights and Measures officials in the market.
•    Supplying underweight bread may lead to consumer dissatisfaction and brand tarnishing.
Operations/Production Department
To establish whether, bread dispatched to the market meets the required weight standards.

attributes.title: Bread Damages Analysis
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that production damages were averaging at 0.29% of the total production and market damages stood at 0.30% of the total sales

Production and Market damages analysis.
attributes.recommendation: •    The branch management should closely monitor the production process to control damages and ensure they remain at acceptable levels.
attributes.effect: Production damages recorded exceeded the acceptable level of 0.2% which implies there was a revenue forfeiture of Kshs. 75,207 for the 43 days period.

value: •    We have controlled the damages coming back from the market, our focus now is to ensure production parameters are adhered to reduce damages resulting from production.

•    Production and market damage overall 0.70%, branch total damage for market and production during the audit stood at 0.59% so control is still within the target. But will try to check the production damages.

•    In the previous audit it was noted that,
•    Production damages accounted for 0.37% of total production, exceeding the standard limit by 0.17%, with a cost implication of Ksh 91,906.14
•    Market damages reached 0.33% of total sales, below the allowable limit of 0.5%

•    Analysis of production and market damages was done for a period of 43 days from 11th April 2025 to 23rd May 2025 to determine whether production and market damages were within the acceptable percentages of 0.20% of the total production and 0.50% of the total sales respectively.
•    Production damages recorded exceeded the acceptable level of 0.2% which implies there was a revenue forfeiture of Kshs. 75,207
Operations/Production Department
To determine whether production and market damages were within the acceptable percentages of 0.20% of the total production and 0.50% of the total sales respectively.

attributes.title: Mixing Charts Analysis
attributes.description:
•    Below is a summary of physical mixing data collected compared to SAP mixing chart summary for the period;

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

•    It was noted that, Average production was 191.86 bags per day, which is 98% of the daily target of 195 bags. Yield achieved during the period was 191.09

•    The table below shows summarized findings on production analysis.
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch should continue to adhere with production standards and also take advantage of the available production capacity whenever the need arises.
•    Data accuracy from the physical mixing charts to SAP should be enhanced to eliminate variance.
attributes.effect:
•    The branch's production capacity utilization was at 98% of the available capacity. This indicates that the branch production capacity is well utilised.
•    Production data transferred to SAP was found to have minor errors resulting to production difference of 165 loaves.

value: •    We have had no major breakdown over the period hence the 98% overall production target achievement otherwise we even been surpassing the production target in days when the demand is high.
•    We had production slow down during oven servicing, this led to the slight production target shortfall.

•    In the previous audit, it was noted that average production was 177.97 bags per day, which is 91.26% of the daily target of 195 bags. Yield achieved during the period was 191.06. There were no cases of remixes for the reviewed period.

•    An analysis of mixing chart summaries was done for a period of 43 days from 11th April 2025 to 23rd May 2025, to confirm production data accuracy from mixing charts to cash flow, SAP, raw materials usage as per the set BOM, production yield and if the set production standards were achieved.

•    The branch's production capacity utilization was at 98% of the available capacity. This indicates that the branch production capacity is well utilised.
•    Production data transferred to SAP was found to have minor errors resulting to production difference of 165 loaves.
Operations/Production Department
To confirm production data accuracy from mixing charts to cash flow, SAP, raw materials usage as per the set BOM, production yield and if the set production standards were achieved.

attributes.title: Cash Count
attributes.description:
•    Cash counted compared to cash flow balance had Kshs -7 variation. 
•    There was one pending IOU amounting to Kshs. 2,000 issued to Levis Ongeri for police cash bail on 13th May 2025.
attributes.recommendation:
•    The branch management should maintain cash controls to ensure there is always 100% cash accountability.
•    The timelines for IOU clearance should be adhered to.
attributes.effect:
•    Cash variance of Kshs. -7 implies that cash controls in place are adequate.
•    The IOU of Kshs. 2,000 issued to Levis Ongeri on 13th May 2025 violate the company rule on the number of days for IOU clearance.

value: •    This well noted
•    Well controlled
•    In the previous audit, Cash counted compared to cash flow balance had a surplus variance of Kshs. +22
•    Verification of cash held at the cash office on 24th May 2025, to confirm cash held by the cashier matches the expected cash and whether the set cash operation standards are adhered to.

•    Cash variance of Kshs. -7 implies that cash controls are in place are adequate. 

•    The IOU of Kshs. 2,000 issued to Levis Ongeri on 13th May 2025 violate the company rule on the number of days for IOU clearance.
Operations/Production Department
To confirm cash held by the cashier matches the expected cash and whether the set cash operation standards are adhered to.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that the production efficiency for the period was 4.46 bags per production worker. 

A summary of production analysis is shown below;
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management should aim to achieve 100% efficiency to prevent incurring unbudgeted labour costs.
attributes.effect: •    Efficiency shortfall implies that the company spent unbudgeted production labour costs amounting to Kshs. 17,805.35 for the 43 days period reviewed.

value: •    The slight inefficiency is noted and we shall ensure it is eliminated.
•    Production efficiency not achieved due to schedule of oven maintenance, where by production is slowed down.
•    In the prior audit, it was noted the actual production efficiency achieved was 4.38 bags per worker, falling slightly below the target.

•    Production efficiency was calculated for period of 43 days from 11th April 2025 to 23rd May 2025. The aim was to determine if the production workers hired achieved the standard production efficiency of 4.5 bags per worker.
•    Efficiency shortfall implies that the company spent unbudgeted production labour costs amounting to Kshs. 17,805.35 for the 43 days period reviewed.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if the production workers hired achieved the standard production efficiency of 4.5 bags per worker.

attributes.title: Packing efficiency
attributes.description:
•    Analysis revealed that the average slicing efficiency for the period was 92.58 crates per slicer. 

The table below illustrates the findings;-
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management should ensure packers are hired based the bread to be packed as well as adequate supervision to eliminate slicing inefficiency.
attributes.effect: •    Packing workers failed to achieve the set efficiency of 97 crates per worker. The inefficiency resulted to a cost implication of Kshs. 46,512 for the 43days period reviewed.

value: •    We shall work closely with supervisors to ensure packers are hired on need basis and that supervision takes place to eliminate inefficiency.
•    Noted and will monitor that
•    In the prior audit, the actual slicing efficiency recorded was 93 crates per slicer, which fell below the target of 97 crates per slicer.
•    Slicing efficiency was calculated over a 43-day period, from 11th April 2025, to 23rd May 2025, to determine whether the KPI of 97 crates per slicer was being met.
•    Packing workers failed to achieve the set efficiency of 97 crates per worker. The inefficiency resulted to a cost implication of Kshs. 46,512 for the 43days period reviewed.
Operations/Production Department
To determine whether the KPI of 97 crates per slicer was being met.

attributes.title: Vehicle fuel consumption analysis
attributes.description: •    It was noted that; consumption data for Motor vehicle KCM 412R was incomplete and KCH 108B had a faulty odometer hence inaccurate mileage. KDC 029X - Bungoma town route vehicle was found to have saved 10.9 litres for 24 days reviewed. The rest of the fleet was found to be within the set standards with minimal variation.
attributes.recommendation: •    Fuel consumption controls should be maintained to caution the company against unbudgeted fuel expenses.
attributes.effect: •    Minimal variations is an indication of efficient fuel consumption monitoring

value: •    We shall continue to ensure sales van consumption is per the set standards.
•    Noted
•    In the prior audit, apart from KBU 741S, KDN 229Y, KDL 256U and KCN 078A which had adverse variations, the rest of the fleet had favorable variation.
•    Motor vehicle fuel consumption analysis was done for the period 1st May 2025 to 24th May 2025, to evaluate compliance with set fuel standard for each vehicle.
•    Minimal variations is an indication of efficient fuel consumption monitoring
Transport/Fleet Department
To evaluate compliance with set fuel standard for each vehicle.

attributes.title: Generator Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that the Fuel consumption rate for the period 1st May 2025 to 25th May 2025 was 58.92Ltrs/Hr as illustrated below;

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

•    Consumption rates comparison for the past 4 months was done as illustrated below;
attributes.recommendation: •    Despite the consumption rate having no major deviation from the previous month’s consumption, audit recommend Generator calibration to establish the accurate standard consumption rate.
attributes.effect: •    Generator fuel consumption rate for the period was found to be within the same range as compared with the preceding months implying good control in place. However, the tracker consumption rate is indicated as 45Ltrs/Hr. which is below the average consumption for the preceding months

value: •    Generator fueling is guided by the tracking system admin and we always abide as directed.
•    We will maintain the trend

•    In the prior audit; it was noted that the Fuel consumption rate for the period 1st April to 12th April 2025 was 44.62 Litres/Hour while at the book records consumption rate stood at 52.72 Litres/Hour.
•    For the month of March 2025, the consumption rate stood at 52.09 Litres/Hour as per the tracker while book records showed a consumption rate of 52.73 Litres/Hour

•    Analysis of the generator’s fuel consumption rate from 1st May 2025 to 25th May 2025 was done and the result compared to previous months consumption to determine if the Consumption rate was within the set standards.

•    Generator fuel consumption rate for the period was found to be within the same range as compared with the preceding months implying good control in place. However, the tracker consumption rate is indicated as 45Ltrs/Hr. which is below the average consumption for the preceding months
Operations/Production Department
To analyze generator fuel consumption rate and note major deviation from the standard rate.
